ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Comparative study of gate oxide in 4H-SiC lateral MOSFETs subjected to post-deposition-annealing in N2O and POCl3

Affiliation.OrgName: Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche - Istituto per la Microelettronica e Microsistemi (CNR-IMM)

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: This paper compares the behavior of the gate oxide in 4H-SiC lateral MOSFETs subjected to post-deposition annealing (PDA) in N2O and POCl3. A significantly higher channel mobility was measured in 4H-SiC MOSFETs subjected to PDA in POCl3 (108 cm2 V−1 s−1) with respect to N2O (19 cm2 V−1 s−1), accompanying a reduction of the interface traps density. Hence, a different temperature coefficient of the mobility and of the threshold voltage was observed in the two cases. According to structural analysis, the gate oxide subjected to PDA in POCl3 showed a different surface morphology than that treated in N2O, as a consequence of the strong incorporation of phosphorous inside the SiO2 matrix during annealing. This latter explained the instability of the electrical behavior of MOS capacitors annealed in POCl3.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Due to its excellent physical properties, like the wide band gap (3.2 eV), the high critical electric field (3 MV/cm) and the high thermal conductivity (4.9 W/cm K [1]), silicon carbide (4H-SiC) is a first choice material for the next generation of efficient power electronic devices [2, 3]. As a matter of fact, in the last two decades significant progresses in material and processing technology resulted in the demonstration of a large variety of devices [4]. Among them, metal-oxide-semiconductor field effect transistors (MOSFETs) on 4H-SiC are considered as a good alternative to replace silicon insulated gate bipolar transistors (IGBTs) in some specific applications [5]. In fact, 4H-SiC MOSFETs can lead to lower static and dynamic losses, while operating at higher switching frequencies than IGBTs, and hence can guarantee a higher efficiency in power converters [6].

In order to improve the electronic quality of the SiO2/SiC interface and to mitigate the channel mobility problem in 4H-SiC MOSFETs, different annealing processes of the gate oxide in NO or N2O have been studied in the last decade [14–18]. Although these nitridation processes could increase the channel mobility up to the range 20–50 cm2 V−1 s−1, a technological breakthrough seems to be necessary to further improve the mobility behavior of 4H-SiC MOSFETs. For this purpose, Okamoto et al. [19] recently proposed the alternative route of post-deposition-annealing (PDA) in phosphoryl chloride POCl3 which enabled them to obtain a channel mobility of 89 cm2 V−1 s−1. These authors argued that during PDA, phosphorous atoms are incorporated in the SiO2 side of the interface rather than inside 4H-SiC, and passivate the interface states, thus increasing the channel mobility.

More recently, Swanson et al. [20] reported an original nanoscale characterization of SiO2/4H-SiC interfaces to compare the effects of PDA in N2O and POCl3 ambient. In particular, a resistivity mapping obtained by scanning spreading resistance microscopy (SSRM) [21] allowed to demonstrate that both nitrogen and phosphorous induce local electrical changes also in the SiC surface exposed to PDA, by a compensation (“counter doping”) of the p-type dopant of the channel region [20]. Even if this work was able to quantify the local electrical effect related to dopant species incorporation during PDA, a comprehensive microstructural analysis of the interface and of the gate oxide was not provided.

Clearly, all the aforementioned results make the topic a subject of extensive debate within the SiC community, and further comparative investigations of the different PDA can be extremely useful to clarify the open and/or controversial issues.

In this paper, a comparative structural and electrical characterization of the SiO2/4H-SiC interfaces in the MOSFETs annealed in N2O and POCl3 is reported, showing how the two PDA processes have a different effect on the overall structure and electrical properties of the gate oxide. In particular, the different surface morphology and electrical behavior observed in MOS capacitors was ascribed to the strong incorporation of phosphorous inside the SiO2 matrix during annealing in POCl3. The instability of the threshold voltage and its anomalous temperature behavior is also discussed.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para: In this work, n-type (0001) 4H-SiC epitaxial layers with a nominal doping concentration of 1×1016 cm−3, grown onto a heavily doped 4H-SiC substrate, were used to fabricate lateral MOSFETs and MOS capacitors. Multiple energy Al-implantation, followed by an annealing at 1650 °C with a carbon capping layer, was carried out to create a p-well region with a doping concentration of about 1017 cm−3 [22]. The source and drain regions were n-type doped by P-implantation annealed at the same temperature. The gate oxide consisted of a 45 nm-thick deposited SiO2 layer, subjected to PDA at atmospheric pressure either in a N2O (1150 °C, 4 h) or a POCl3 (1000 °C, 1 h) ambient. These annealing conditions allowed minimizing the interface states density and the interface reoxidation. Annealed nickel films were used as ohmic contacts in the n-type source/drain regions.

The current voltage (I–V) and capacitance voltage (C–V) measurements of the devices were carried out in a Karl–Suss probe station using an Agilent B1500A parameter analyzer. Lateral MOSFETs were used as test vehicle to determine the field effect channel mobility μ FE and the threshold voltage V th. Vertical MOS capacitors were used to estimate the interface state density D
it using Terman’s method [23] and to study the reliability of the gate oxides subjected to different PDA treatments. Although the extraction of the D
it values in SiC by C–V methods has been widely questioned [24], our approach is suitable to make the direct comparisons of the two PDA conditions.
Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) combined with energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis was performed in order to monitor the structure and estimate the composition of the annealed gate oxide.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
The electrical behavior of the lateral 4H-SiC MOSFETs subjected to PDA in N2O or POCl3 is summarized in Fig. 1. In particular, Fig. 1(a) shows the transfer characteristics (I
D –V
G ) of the devices acquired in the saturation region, at a drain voltage V
D =10 V. As can be seen, a notably higher current level is measured in the devices annealed in POCl3 with respect to those treated in N2O. As a matter of fact, a higher channel conductivity is obtained upon annealing in POCl3 [20]. From the transfer characteristics reported in Fig. 1a, the values of the threshold voltage V th could be determined from a linear fit of the
$I _{D} ^{1/2}$ vs. V
g plot. In particular, rather similar values of V th were measured in both cases, i.e., 10 V and 10.8 V after PDA in N2O and POCl3, respectively. It is worth noting that a positive threshold voltage was found in our devices after PDA in POCl3. However, similar PDA processes can lead to much lower V th values (i.e., close to zero), depending on the properties of the p-type body region and of the gate oxide [19].
Fig. 1
(a) Drain current (at V
D =10 V) as a function of gate voltage for lateral 4H-SiC MOSFETs, with a 45 nm thick SiO2 gate after post-deposition-annealing in N2O or in POCl3 ambient. (b) Field effect mobility as a function of the gate voltage for the same devices

The field effect mobility μ FE, determined from the I
D –V
D characteristics of the MOSFETs in the linear region at room temperature, is reported in Fig. 1b as a function of the gate bias V
g for the two PDA conditions. The maximum values of the mobility (peak mobility) were 19 cm2 V−1 s−1 and 108 cm2 V−1 s−1, for the devices subjected to PDA in N2O or POCl3, respectively. The dramatic increase of the channel mobility observed after PDA in POCl3 could be associated to a reduction of the interface state density D
it close to the conduction band edge. The values of D
it at about E
c −E
it =0.2 eV, measured by the C–V analysis of MOS capacitors, were 5.7×1011 eV−1 cm−2 and 1.8×1012 eV−1 cm−2, respectively, for the PDA in POCl3 and N2O.

Several authors have described the channel mobility in 4H-SiC MOSFETs considering different physical components (bulk mobility, surface roughness, phonon scattering, Coulomb scattering) using the Matthiessen’s rule, i.e., where the reciprocal of the total mobility is the reciprocal sum of each mobility component [25–27]. In these works, the temperature dependence of the channel mobility was studied in order to get insights into the mechanism ruling the carrier transport in the MOSFET channel. With the same purpose, also in our case, both the field effective mobility μ FE and the threshold voltage V th were measured at different temperatures in the range 298–423 K. The data, reported in Fig. 2a and 2b, show a different behavior of these parameters in the two PDA conditions. In particular, in the MOSFET annealed in N2O (Fig. 2a) the mobility increased with the temperature (from 19 cm2 V−1 s−1 at room temperature to 25 cm2 V−1 s−1 at 423 K), while the threshold voltage decreased in the same temperature range (from 10 V to 6.24 V). On the other hand, the MOSFET annealed in POCl3 (Fig. 2b) showed the opposite trend, i.e., with the mobility decreasing with the temperature (from 108 cm2 V−1 s−1 to 75 cm2 V−1 s−1 at 423 K) and the threshold voltage increasing with temperature (from 10.8 V to 13.3 V).
Fig. 2
Peak field effect mobility μ FE (bold symbols) and threshold voltage V th (open symbols) as a function of the temperature for lateral 4H-SiC MOSFETs, with a 45 nm thick SiO2 gate after post-deposition-annealing in (a) N2O or (b) POCl3 ambient. The lines connecting the data points are to guide the eye only

The observed temperature dependence of the mobility indicates that Coulomb scattering governs the carrier transport in the channel after PDA in N2O. On the other hand, a decreasing mobility with increasing temperature in the case of PDA in POCl3 suggests rather that phonon scattering dominates over the other contributions. Considering the threshold voltage V th, while the sample annealed in N2O exhibits a negative temperature coefficient of the threshold voltage that is usual for SiO2/SiC MOSFETs in the presence of interface states and oxide trapped charges [5], an anomalous behavior is observed after PDA in POCl3, where V th increases with the temperature. We argue that this anomalous temperature behavior of V th (Fig. 2b) is a consequence of the gate oxide modification induced by PDA in POCl3 as will be discussed later.
In order to better clarify the effects of those PDA on the gate oxide, additional structural and electrical characterization were carried out and are reported in the following.

First a cross-section TEM analysis has been performed close to the SiO2/4H-SiC interface in the gate region of the devices. The cross-sectional samples were prepared by cutting the TEM-slice along the [11–20] misorentation direction, in order to visualize the 4H-SiC “surface steps.” Figure 3 shows the TEM micrographs of the gate region for the samples annealed in N2O and in POCl3. In these low magnification images, one can easily recognize the SiO2 gate dielectric over the 4H-SiC. On the top of the oxide, the poly-Si electrode is also visible. The first evidence arising from this analysis is that only a very small difference in the gate oxide thickness can be seen in the two cases. In fact, the value of the thickness measured by TEM analysis is 46 nm in the case of the sample annealed in N2O, while it ranges between 46 and 50 nm in the case of the sample annealed in POCl3.
Fig. 3
Cross section TEM micrographs acquired in the gate region of the MOSFETs, for the device annealed in (a) N2O or (b) POCl3

Rather than the bare oxide thickness value, the most interesting feature is the different morphology of the surfaces of the oxide after PDA treatment. In fact, the oxide layer treated in N2O exhibits a conformal coating, i.e., with periodical undulations (steps) along the [11–20] direction. On the other hand, in the case of the sample annealed in POCl3 a high degree of planarization of the oxide surface is observed (flat upper interface with the poly-Si). For this reason, the oxide thickness extracted by the TEM images ranges between 46 and 50 nm.

To understand these morphological differences, high resolution TEM and EDX analysis were carried out in the sample subjected to POA in POCl3 and are shown in Fig. 4a and 4b, respectively. The high resolution image of the SiO2/4H-SiC interface (Fig. 4a) was intentionally taken to visualize the edge of a surface step. As can be seen, the sample surface resembles the geometry of the faceted structure commonly observed in 4H-SiC surfaces [28–31]. Indeed, also in the present case the angle measured between the two facets is about 18°. This latter indicates that an anisotropy of the reoxidation process of the SiC substrate under PDA in POCl3 is unlikely to occur.
Fig. 4
(a) High resolution TEM micrograph of the SiO2/4H-SiC interface after annealing in POCl3 (b) EDX compositional analysis of the elements acquired in the interface region

On the other hand, compositional analysis of the elements determined by EDX (Fig. 4b) clearly shows that a significant amount of phosphorus has diffused inside the oxide after POA in POCl3 and is almost homogeneously distributed within the insulating layer. From the quantitative analysis of the EDX signals of the elements present inside the sample, it was possible to estimate a phosphorous concentration of about 12 at%. The dissolution of such a large amount of phosphorous inside the SiO2 network during annealing in POCl3 typically results in the formation of a phosphosilicate glass [32] and can explain the planarization of the interface between the SiO2 and the poly-Si observed in Fig. 3b. In fact, it is known that P-doped SiO2 can soften and reflow above 950 °C, creating a smooth topography that is beneficial for the subsequent poly-Si deposition [32].

The C–V curves of the MOS capacitors annealed in the different atmospheres are shown in Fig. 5. Evidently, different values of the accumulation capacitance C ox are measured in the two cases, i.e., 6.93×10−8 F/cm2 in N2O and 6.2×10−8 F/cm2 in POCl3. Considering the thickness values of the oxide layers measured by TEM analysis (46 nm for N2O and an average value of 48 nm for POCl3), the lower C ox of the oxide annealed in POCl3 can be ascribed to a 7 % lowering of the dielectric permittivity. An analogous C–V analysis on 4H-SiC MOS capacitors annealed in POCl3 provided values of the permittivity in the range of 3.8–4.1 [19]. As a matter of fact, the dielectric properties of P-doped SiO2 depend on the amount of phosphorous, on the deposition temperature and method [33]. Moreover, from Fig. 5a, it possible to observe that the experimental C–V curves are slightly shifted in the positive direction of the bias with respect to the ideal ones (dashed lines) calculated assuming no interface states and fixed charges. This behavior indicates the presence of a small amount of negative trapped charges in both cases, whose density was estimated to be about 3–4×1011 cm−2.
Fig. 5
(a) C–V characteristics of 4H-SiC MOS capacitors annealed in either N2O and in POCl3. The ideal C–V curves are also reported for comparison. (b) Variation of the flat band voltage ΔV FB as a function of the increasing electric field applied to the gate oxide for the two PDA conditions

In order to have an additional information on the reliability of the gate oxide, the stability of the flat band voltage V FB of MOS capacitors was monitored by cyclically repeating C–V measurements, sweeping the bias from accumulation to depletion with increasing starting voltages at each C–V curve. Under these conditions, the electric field in the oxide is increased at each sweep. The variation of the flat band voltage (ΔV FB) determined in a representative set of C–V curves with respect to the initial value is reported in Fig. 5b as a function of the increasing electric field applied to the gate oxide. Evidently, while the sample annealed in N2O shows only a slight increase of ΔV FB (<0.3 V), different behavior is shown by the sample annealed in POCl3. In fact, in this case a large flat band voltage variation ΔV FB=2 V is observed already below 5 MV/cm.

It can be argued that the significant positive flat band shift observed upon application of an electric field is correlated with the presence of “P-related defects” responsible for a negative charge trapping in the oxide. In particular, the SiO2 network is transformed into a phosphosilicate glass by the incorporation of P-atoms during annealing in POCl3. In this structure, the largest fraction of P-atoms replaces the Si atom of the SiO4 tetrahedron, forming a double bond (P=O) and three single P–O bonds. Any deviation from this network configuration can be considered a P-related defect [34], that can act as a center for charge trapping. In particular, the generation of the so-called P2 or P4 defects, whose formation involves the trapping of a negative charge [34], could explain the positive shift of the flat band voltage during cyclic C–V measurements. However, additional spectroscopic measurements are required to fully confirm this hypothesis.

Considering a flat band voltage shift of about 2 V measured below 5 MV/cm (see Fig. 5b), a trapped charge density of 7.75×1011 charges/cm2 can be estimated. Hence, assuming they are homogeneously distributed inside the 46 nm thick layer, the density of the P-related defects responsible for the negative charge trapping during stress can be estimated to be 1.68×1017 cm−3. This is a reasonable number, considering that it is only a very small fraction of the phosphorous incorporated in the matrix.

It is worth noting that besides the electrically active defects, polarization phenomena are likely to occur in similar glass structures [35, 36]. Hence, it cannot be ruled out that the build-up of a polarization charge in the P-doped SiO2 layer under the application of a bias also contributes to the instability of the C–V curves in MOS capacitors. In this sense, since the polarizability of P-doped SiO2 is proportional to the reverse of the temperature [35], the anomalous increase of the threshold voltage with the temperature measured in the lateral MOSFETs after PDA in POCl3 could be a consequence of the attenuation of the polarization effects with increasing temperature. However, we believe that in our case polarization charges are not the dominant factor, since the flat band voltage shift was not reversible, i.e., could be not recovered by the application of an opposite bias stress.

Finally, I–V measurements were carried out on the MOS capacitors, with the aim to get more insights in the electron conduction mechanism through the gate oxide. Figure 6 shows the typical forward characteristics of the n-type 4H-SiC MOS capacitors with the gate oxide subjected to PDA in N2O and POCl3. The current density J is reported in a semilog scale as a function of the electric field E ox. As can be seen, while the breakdown field of the two oxides is very similar (11.31 MV/cm and 10.74 MV/cm, for N2O and POCl3, respectively), the MOS treated in POCl3 exhibits a higher leakage current than those annealed in N2O, at least up to a field E ox of about 7 MV/cm.
Fig. 6
Current density as a function of the electric field in 4H-SiC MOS capacitors annealed either N2O and in POCl3

The characteristics of the devices annealed in N2O exhibits a region of linearity above 5 MV/cm, which indicates a Fowler–Nordheim (FN) tunneling mechanism [23]. From the expression of the FN current density, using a ratio between the free electron mass and the effective electron mass in the SiO2 of m/m ox=0.42 [37] a barrier height of 2.45 eV (between the SiC and SiO2 conduction band) could be estimated in our case. This value is very close to that reported in literature by other authors [38]. On the other hand, in spite of the similar breakdown strength, the high leakage current and the non-linearity of the I–V curves of the MOS annealed in POCl3 suggest that FN tunneling is not the dominant mechanism for the conduction through the insulating layer. In particular, the non-ideal behavior can be attributed to an enhanced conduction through the highly defective oxide structure with increasing applied electric field.

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: This paper reports a comparison between the electrical and structural properties of SiO2 gate dielectrics in lateral 4H-SiC MOSFETs annealed in N2O and POCl3. The significant increase of the channel mobility (up to 108 cm2 V−1 s−1) measured in 4H-SiC MOSFETs annealed in POCl3 with respect to N2O also resulted in a different temperature dependence of mobility. However, the devices exhibited a positive threshold voltage under both PDA conditions.

The advantages of the POCl3 process in terms of channel mobility increase and interface state density reduction were accompanied by notably morphological and compositional changes of the gate oxide. In particular, after PDA in POCl3 a planarization of the oxide surface occurs, due to the strong incorporation of phosphorous inside the SiO2 matrix and the consequent reflow of the P-doped oxide during annealing. The presence of a high phosphorous concentration in the gate oxide determines an instability of the electrical behavior of MOS capacitors and an anomalous temperature behavior of the MOSFET threshold voltage. The electrical results suggest that the presence of “P-related defects” is responsible for a negative charge trapping in the oxide.
According to the above results, we believe that P-based PDA of SiO2/SiC interfaces deserve further attention to reliably control the mobility and the threshold voltage of the 4H-SiC MOSFETs channel.
